title: page fault
html:
Page Fault (Short Note)

A page fault occurs when a process tries to access a page that is not currently in TLB then in  RAM. This triggers an interrupt, and the OS must handle it.

Types of Page Faults

  1. Minor Page Fault (Soft Page Fault)

    • The page is in swap space or another memory area but not mapped to the process.
    • The OS simply updates the page table without disk access.

  2. Major Page Fault (Hard Page Fault)

    • The page is not in RAM, requiring a disk read.
    • The OS loads the page from disk (swap) into RAM and updates the page table.

Steps in Handling a Page Fault

  1. CPU detects the missing page â†’ Raises a page fault exception.
  2. OS checks if the address is valid â†’ If invalid, it raises a segmentation fault.
  3. If valid but missing, the OS finds a free frame (or evicts an old page).
  4. Loads the missing page from disk into RAM.
  5. Updates the page table and TLB.
  6. Resumes process execution from the faulting instruction.

Performance Impact

  • Page faults slow down execution due to disk access.
  • TLB and caching help minimize page faults.
  • Efficient page replacement algorithms (e.g., LRU, Clock) reduce unnecessary page faults.
